description: Topics from among the following: logic, sets, calculus, probability, history and philosophy of mathematics, game theory, geometry, and their relevance to contemporary science and society.
name: IDEAS IN MATHEMATICS

values.comments:
This course is an introductory mathematics course to topics in logic, calculus, probability and geometry, with an eye toward the history and philosophy of mathematics. Such areas are set in the context of contemporary applications in science and society such as game theory.

Most students felt this course was “neither interesting nor stimulating.” One student even described it as “totally worthless,” while another proposed that it should be dropped from Penn’s curriculum or turned into a small seminar that would enable meaningful discussion and enhance learning. A majority of students felt misled by the course description and purpose, resulting in frustration with the content, grading and class format. Many seemed to think that this semester was largely uncharacteristic of years past and were duly disappointed as the semester progressed.

Many students were also frustrated by grading of homework assignments and found the work required tedious and overly time-consuming. Exams were challenging, and several students felt the second midterm was unfairly difficult. One student noted, “Unlike many of my classmates, I attended all the lectures, but I feel like it did not help me to prepare for the graded coursework.”

Students were also discontented with Professor Gressman’s teaching style, which they described as “boring,” “slow” and sometimes “repetitive.” One student wrote, “Reading verbatim from the slides is not stimulating.” However, many appreciated Professor Gressman’s passion for the subject and approachability during office hours. As one student noted, “Professor Gressman clearly loves the material and wants us to learn it well.” Others appreciated Gressman’s clarity and the quality of his lecture notes which helped them prepare for exams.

Students who took this course were not math majors and did not necessarily have a strong background or interest in mathematics. This course fulfills Natural Science and Mathematics sector requirement for the College. Given their background with the subject matter and the difficulty of the course, many students struggled to obtain their desired grade.
